case_id: Mable George v. State of Kerala (2019) 11 SCC 341
facts: Marriage between Nithu (deceased) and Sanu George (Accused No. 3 - A3, son of Appellant Mable George) solemnized on February 11, 2007.
Nithu was found hanging in her matrimonial home on July 14, 2007, approximately five months after the marriage.
Initial FIR registered under Section 174 CrPC (unnatural death).
Following complaints by the deceased's parents alleging dowry harassment, the High Court ordered a re-investigation.
Chargesheet filed against Mable George (Appellant/Mother-in-law - A1), George Kutty (Father-in-law - A2), and Sanu George (Husband - A3) under Sections 498A, 304B, and 306 read with Section 34 IPC.
Prosecution alleged demands for remaining dowry (gold ornaments) and money for A3's business/vehicle, coupled with mental and physical harassment.
Key prosecution witnesses included PW1 (father), PW2 (mother), PW4 (uncle), PW5 (priest), PW6 (relative), and PW7 (neighbour), testifying to demands and harassment.
Post-mortem report (PW17 - Forensic Surgeon) indicated death due to asphyxia consistent with hanging; ligature mark observed.
Trial Court convicted A1, A2, and A3 under Sections 498A, 304B, and 306 r/w 34 IPC. Sentenced to RI for 2 years (498A), 7 years (304B), and 7 years (306), concurrently.
High Court, on appeal, acquitted A3 (husband) but confirmed the conviction and sentence for A1 (Mable George) and A2 (George Kutty).
Mable George (A1) filed the present appeal before the Supreme Court. A2 did not appeal.
Supreme Court specifically noted the short duration between marriage and death (approx. 5 months).
ipc_sections: Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention)
Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Cruelty under Section 498A IPC established through consistent witness testimony regarding dowry demands and harassment by the appellant (A1).
precedents: Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 5 SCC 177 (Defines scope of cruelty)
K.V. Prakash Babu v. State of Karnataka (2016) 11 SCC 178 (Distinguishes cruelty from ordinary marital discord)
Rajbir v. State of Haryana (2010) 15 SCC 116 (Emphasizes seriousness of dowry-related cruelty)
elements: She was subjected to cruelty or harassment.
Such cruelty or harassment was by her husband or any relative of her husband (A1 - mother-in-law).
Cruelty involved wilful conduct likely to drive suicide or cause grave injury OR harassment related to unlawful dowry demands.

counter_arguments.loophole: Witnesses (PW1, PW2, etc.) are close relatives of the deceased and thus 'interested witnesses'; their testimony requires careful scrutiny and independent corroboration, which may be lacking.
supporting_precedents: Surinder Kaur v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 124 (Caution needed for testimony of interested witnesses)
Bhaskar Lal Sharma v. State (Delhi) (2012) SCC OnLine Del 483 (Vague allegations insufficient for 498A)
Neelu Chopra v. Bharti (2009) 10 SCC 184 (Need for specific allegations, not omnibus ones)

prosecution_arguments.argument: All ingredients of Section 304B IPC are satisfied, raising the statutory presumption under Section 113B of the Indian Evidence Act against the appellant.
precedents: Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 (Essentials of 304B and 'soon before death')
State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1 (Scope of Section 113B presumption)
Major Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 5 SCC 201 (Continuous harassment can constitute 'soon before death')
elements: Death occurred otherwise than under normal circumstances (hanging).
Death occurred within seven years of marriage (within 5 months).
Deceased was subjected to cruelty or harassment by husband or relative (A1).
Such cruelty or harassment was for, or in connection with, any demand for dowry.
Such cruelty or harassment was meted out 'soon before her death'.

counter_arguments.loophole: The prosecution failed to establish a proximate and live link between the alleged dowry demand/harassment and the death. 'Soon before death' requires more than general allegations spread over months.
supporting_precedents: Rajinder Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 6 SCC 477 (Meaning of 'soon before death'; must be proximate link)
Tarsem Singh v. State of Punjab (2008) 16 SCC 155 (Cruelty must be proximate cause, not remote)
Baijnath v. State of M.P. (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Burden on prosecution to prove foundational facts for 113B presumption)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The persistent cruelty and harassment by the appellant created circumstances that instigated or aided the deceased to commit suicide, constituting abetment under Section 306 IPC.
precedents: Ramesh Kumar v. State of Chhattisgarh (2001) 9 SCC 618 (Mental cruelty under 498A can amount to abetment)
Praveen Pradhan v. State of Uttaranchal (2012) 9 SCC 734 (Circumstances created by accused leaving no option)
Chitresh Kumar Chopra v. State (NCT of Delhi) (2009) 16 SCC 605 (Mens rea requirement for instigation)
elements: The appellant abetted the commission of suicide.
Abetment involved instigation, conspiracy, or intentional aiding.

counter_arguments.loophole: Abetment requires a positive act or specific conduct aimed at pushing the deceased towards suicide. Mere harassment, even if cruel under 498A, does not automatically meet the higher threshold for Section 306 without proof of mens rea to abet.
supporting_precedents: Sanju @ Sanjay Singh Sengar v. State of M.P. (2002) 5 SCC 371 (Need for positive act; mere quarreling insufficient)
Gangula Mohan Reddy v. State of A.P. (2010) 1 SCC 750 (Requires active role or direct act leading to suicide)
State of West Bengal v. Orilal Jaiswal (1994) 1 SCC 73 (High degree of certainty required for 306 conviction)

defense_arguments.argument: Allegations of cruelty and dowry demand are vague, generalized, and lack specific instances or dates. Evidence primarily from interested family members, lacking independent corroboration.
edge_cases: Distinguishing between routine marital friction/financial discussions and unlawful dowry demands/harassment.
Credibility assessment of witnesses closely related to the deceased.
precedents: Neelu Chopra v. Bharti (2009) 10 SCC 184 (General allegations insufficient)
Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand (2010) 7 SCC 667 (Tendency to implicate entire family)
Kahkashan Kausar @ Sonam v. State of Bihar (2022) 6 SCC 599 (Reinforces need for specific allegations against each accused in 498A cases)

defense_arguments.argument: Prosecution failed to establish the crucial 'soon before death' element for Section 304B. No evidence connects specific acts of dowry-related cruelty by the appellant immediately preceding the suicide.
edge_cases: Interpretation of 'soon before death' â€“ temporal proximity vs. continuous conduct.
Whether the presumption under Section 113B Evidence Act was properly invoked or sufficiently rebutted.
precedents: Rajinder Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 6 SCC 477 ('Soon before' requires proximate link, not remote past)
Appasaheb v. State of Maharashtra (2007) 9 SCC 721 (Distinction between 'dowry demand' and other financial demands)
Sher Singh @ Partapa v. State of Haryana (2015) 3 SCC 724 (Presumption under 113B is rebuttable)

defense_arguments.argument: No evidence of instigation or positive act by the appellant that directly led to the suicide. Conviction under Section 306 requires proof of mens rea and actions leaving the deceased with no choice, which is absent.
edge_cases: High standard of proof for abetment compared to cruelty.
Possibility of suicide due to other personal reasons or hypersensitivity, not attributable to appellant's actions.
precedents: Sanju @ Sanjay Singh Sengar v. State of M.P. (2002) 5 SCC 371 (Abetment requires positive act)
Gangula Mohan Reddy v. State of A.P. (2010) 1 SCC 750 (Clear mens rea needed for 306)
Amalendu Pal v. State of West Bengal (2010) 1 SCC 707 (Sensitivity of deceased not enough; accused's actions must be the direct cause)

defense_arguments.argument: The conviction under both Section 304B and Section 306 IPC is questionable, suggesting uncertainty in the prosecution's case regarding the exact nature of the offense (dowry death vs. abetted suicide). While legally possible, it indicates a lack of definitive proof for either.
edge_cases: Legal permissibility of charging/convicting under both sections vs. potential contradiction in underlying facts.
Whether evidence supports the higher threshold of Section 306 beyond Section 304B.
precedents: Smt. Shanti v. State of Haryana (1991) 1 SCC 371 (Sections not mutually exclusive but distinct)
Rajbir v. State of Haryana (2010) 15 SCC 116 (Suggests framing 306 charge when 304B is main charge)
Jasvinder Saini v. State (Govt. of NCT of Delhi) (2013) 7 SCC 256 (Discusses framing alternative charges, but conviction usually under one based on evidence)

judgment.outcome: Partially Allowed Appeal. Appellant Mable George acquitted under Section 306 IPC. Conviction under Section 498A and Section 304B IPC upheld. Sentence under Section 304B (7 years RI) maintained. Sentence under Section 498A reduced to period already undergone.
reasoning: Evidence of PW1, PW2, etc., sufficiently established persistent demands for dowry and harassment, constituting cruelty under Section 498A.
All ingredients of Section 304B were met: unnatural death within 7 years of marriage, preceded by dowry-related cruelty.
The continuous harassment over the 5-month period satisfied the 'soon before death' requirement, establishing a proximate link.
The presumption under Section 113B of the Evidence Act was correctly invoked against the appellant and not sufficiently rebutted.

Evidence was insufficient to meet the higher threshold for abetment of suicide under Section 306 IPC. No specific act of instigation or direct aiding by the appellant towards the commission of suicide was proven beyond reasonable doubt.
While cruelty was established, it did not automatically translate into the positive act required for abetment under Section 306.
